name: Kava (Piper methysticum)
summary: Kava is a traditional South Pacific plant-based supplement used for its calming, anxiolytic, and sleep-promoting properties. Its active compounds, kavalactones, modulate neurotransmission to reduce anxiety and promote relaxation.
description: Kava, derived from the root of the Piper methysticum plant, has been consumed ceremonially in Pacific Island cultures for centuries as a calming and social beverage. Its bioactive compounds, known as kavalactones, influence GABAergic, dopaminergic, and serotonergic pathways to reduce anxiety and induce relaxation. Modern use focuses on anxiety relief, sleep support, and stress reduction. While generally effective, kava has been associated with rare but serious hepatotoxicity, leading to restrictions or warnings in several countries.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical treatment)

monitoring_required: Liver function tests for prolonged use
Signs of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain)

items: Relief of mild to moderate anxiety
Improvement of sleep onset and quality

sections.text: Kavalactones, the active compounds in kava, enhance GABA-A receptor binding, inhibit reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, and modulate voltage-gated ion channels, resulting in anxiolytic and sedative effects.

adult.typical: Standardized extracts providing 60–120 mg kavalactones daily, divided into 2–3 doses
adult.note: Short-term use recommended (≤8 weeks). Avoid exceeding 250 mg/day of kavalactones.

sections.pediatric: Not recommended due to safety concerns.

sections.text: Calming effects may appear within 30–60 minutes. Benefits for anxiety and sleep typically observed within 1–2 weeks of consistent use.

other: Reports of hepatotoxicity have led to restrictions in some countries.
Avoid alcohol and other hepatotoxic drugs when using kava.
Long-term or high-dose use may cause 'kava dermopathy' (dry, scaly skin).

items: Liver function (ALT, AST, bilirubin) if used >4 weeks

sections.pregnancy: Not recommended (insufficient safety data, potential risk)
sections.lactation: Avoid (excreted in breast milk, safety not established)
sections.geriatrics: Use with caution; monitor liver function and sedation

sections.text: Not generally required; however, abrupt discontinuation after heavy or prolonged use may cause rebound anxiety.

items: More effective for anxiety than insomnia in clinical trials.
Liver toxicity cases are controversial; may be linked to extraction methods or pre-existing conditions.
Traditional kava beverages may have different safety profiles compared to concentrated extracts.

items.label: Cochrane Review on Kava for Anxiety
